revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Military personnel from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to [[:Category:Military personnel from Philadelphia]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2016 September 6]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = James A. Zimble, M.D. |image = James A. Zimble.jpg |image_size = 150px |caption = James A. Zimble, M.D. |birth_date = {{birth date|1933|10|12}} |birth_place = [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States]] |death_date = {{death date and age|2011|12|14|1933|10|12}} |death_place = [[New London, Connecticut]] |residence = New London, Connecticut |citizenship = United States |nationality = United States |ethnicity = [[Caucasian race|Caucasian]] |field = [[physician]] |work_institutions = |alma_mater = [[Franklin & Marshall College]], [[Perelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania|University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''James Allen Zimble''' (October 12, 1933 – December 14, 2011) was a [[Officer (armed forces)|commissioned officer]] in the [[Medical Corps (United States Navy)|Medical Corps]] of the [[United States Navy]]. His Navy career spanned 35 years of service, beginning in 1956 at the rank of [[Ensign (rank)#United States|ensign]] and ending in 1991 at the rank of [[Vice admiral (United States)|vice admiral]]. He served as the 30th [[Surgeon General of the United States Navy]] from 1987 to 1991. After retiring from the Navy in 1991, Zimble was appointed President of the [[Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences]] in [[Bethesda, Maryland]]. He remained in that position until 2004.
==Early life== Zimble, an only child, was born on 12 October 1933 in [[Philadelphia]]. Shortly after his birth, the family moved to [[Little Rock, Arkansas]], where they lived until 1946. His parents, both [[Hearing impairment|hearing impaired]], were employed as teachers of deaf children. In 1946, the Zimble family relocated back to Philadelphia.<ref name=USU2011>{{cite web|author=Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences|authorlink=Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences|title=James Allen Zimble, 1991 to 2004|work=Office of the President: USU Past Presidents|publisher=Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences|location=Bethesda, Maryland|year=2011|url=http://www.usuhs.mil/pres/pastpresidents.html#zimble|accessdate=2011-12-17}}</ref>
==Education and training== Zimble enrolled in [[Franklin & Marshall College]] in [[Lancaster, Pennsylvania]] in 1951, from where he earned a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in 1955 and was a member of the [[Pi Lambda Phi]] fraternity.<ref name="2010directory">Membership Directory, 2010, Pi Lambda Phi Inc.</ref> Later that year, he matriculated in the [[Perelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania|University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine]]. The following year, he accepted a commission in the [[United States Navy Reserve]] at the rank of ensign. Zimble received his [[Doctor of Medicine]] degree in 1959. He completed his [[Internship (medicine)|internship]] at the U.S. Naval Hospital at [[St. Albans, Queens|St. Albans, New York]] from 1959 to 1960, then trained in [[Diving medicine|undersea medicine]] at the [[Naval Support Activity Panama City#Tenant commands|Naval School, Diving and Salvage]] (NSDS, often referred to as the U.S. Navy Deep Sea Diving School) and also at the U.S. Navy [[Nuclear Power School]] until 1961. Zimble returned to St. Albans in 1963 for [[Residency (medicine)|residency training]] in [[Obstetrics and gynaecology|obstetrics and gynecology]].<ref name=USU2011/>
==Career== Serving as the submarine medical officer for the [[plankowner|commissioning crew]] of the ''[[USS John Marshall (SSBN-611)|USS John Marshall]]'' (SSBN-611) from 1961 to 1963, he received the [[Submarine Medical insignia]].<ref name=USU2011/>
After completing his residency in 1966, he was assigned to the obstetrics and gynecology department at the U.S. Naval Hospital at the [[Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton]] in [[California]]; he remained there until 1970.<ref name=USU2011/>
On 1 August 1970, while on his way to report for his next assignment (at the U.S. Naval Hospital at the [[Philadelphia Naval Shipyard]]), Zimble was involved in a motor vehicle accident which resulted in his being hospitalized for a year and a half. During this time, he began to redirect his efforts towards a career in executive medicine. In late 1971, he finally reported to the U.S. Naval Hospital in Philadelphia, where he remained on the medical staff until the following year. From 1972 to 1976, Zimble was Chief of OB/GYN and Director of Clinical Services at the U.S. Naval Hospital at the [[Naval Air Station Lemoore]] in [[Lemoore, California]]. From 1976 to 1978, he was assigned as Director of Clinical Services at the Naval Regional Medical Center at the [[Naval Station Long Beach]] in [[Long Beach, California]]. From 1978 to 1981, he was [[Commanding officer|Commanding Officer]] of the [[Naval Hospital Orlando|Naval Regional Medical Center]] in [[Orlando, Florida]].<ref name=USU2011/>
In 1981, Zimble was promoted to [[Flag officer|flag rank]] and was assigned as Medical Officer of the Marine Corps. He held that office, stationed at [[Headquarters Marine Corps]], until 1983. Later that year, RADM Zimble was promoted to Fleet Surgeon for the [[United States Fleet Forces Command|Commander in Chief, U.S. Atlantic Fleet]] (CINCLANTFLT) and Medical Advisor to the [[Supreme Allied Commander Atlantic]] (SACLANT). In that post, he was responsible for the health of United States Navy and [[United States Marine Corps]] personnel and contingency and wartime planning of medical support to operational forces.<ref name=USU2011/>
In 1986, RADM Zimble was again promoted, this time as the Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategic Planning and Medical Program Management (subsequently redesignated as the [http://fhp.osd.mil Force Health Protection & Readiness (FHP&R)]) in the Office of the [[Assistant Secretary of Defense for Health Affairs]]. In this role, Zimble was the Executive Secretary of the Defense Department’s Advisory Committee on [[graduate medical education]]. He was responsible for the oversight of the development of an integrated global plan for [[military medicine]] and the implementation of the Military Health Services System Sizing model.<ref name=USU2011/>
In 1987, Zimble was promoted to vice admiral (VADM) and held the office of [[Surgeon General of the United States Navy]]. As Navy Surgeon General, Zimble was the principal medical advisor to the [[United States Department of the Navy]]. He was responsible for developing and establishing overall naval [[Health policy|health care policies]] and priorities, contingency and wartime planning, and program development in support of more than 2.8 million United States Navy and Marine Corps active duty and retired beneficiaries and their families. During this period, Zimble also presided over the disestablishment of the Naval Medical Command and the re-establishment of the Navy Bureau of Medicine and Surgery (BUMED). He also oversaw the deployment of the Navy's two [[hospital ship]]s (USNS ''[[USNS Mercy (T-AH-19)|Mercy]]'' and USNS ''[[USNS Comfort (T-AH-20)|Comfort]]''), the fleet hospitals, and Medical Department personnel for [[Gulf War|Operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm]].<ref name=NMI2011/>
Upon his retirement from the Navy in 1991, VADM Zimble was replaced as Surgeon General of the United States Navy by VADM Donald F. Hagen.<ref name=USU2011/>
Later that year, Zimble was appointed by [[Dick Cheney]], the [[United States Secretary of Defense]], as President of the [[Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences]] (USUHS) in Bethesda, Maryland. As President of USUHS, Zimble established the USUHS [[Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences#USU Graduate School of Nursing|Graduate School of Nursing]] in 1993. Since that time, the USUHS GSN has grown from its charter class of two students in one advanced practice nursing discipline in 1993 to more than 530 graduates in five program areas. Zimble also established the National Capital Area Medical Simulation Center, which has since become a world class model for medical simulation education. Zimble remained President of USUHS until 2004.<ref name=Newswise2011>{{cite web|author=Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences|title=James A. Zimble, Fourth Uniformed Services University President and former Navy Surgeon General, Dies|work=Newswise|publisher=Newswise, Inc.|location=Charlottesville Virginia|date=2011-12-16|url=http://www.newswise.com/articles/james-a-zimble-fourth-uniformed-services-university-president-and-former-navy-surgeon-general-dies|accessdate=2011-12-17}}</ref>
==Personal life== Dr. James A. Zimble married the former Mona C. Melton. He had three children, five step-children, and twelve grandchildren.<ref name=Newswise2011/>
==Death== Zimble died on December 14, 2011 of coronary artery disease<ref name=NMI2011>{{cite web|vauthors=Herman JK, Sobocinski AB, Rhode M |title={{sic|In Memo|rium|hide=y|expected=In Memoriam (but it's incorrect in the source)}}: VADM James A. Zimble, MC, USN, Ret. (1933-2011)|work=Tranquillity, Solace & Mercy: A History Showcase of the U.S. Navy Medical Department|publisher=Rush Education and Conference Center, Navy Medicine Institute|location=Washington, DC|date=2011-12-14|url=http://usstranquillity.blogspot.com/2011/12/in-memorium-vadm-james-zimble-mc-usn.html|accessdate=2011-12-17}}</ref> at Lawrence and Memorial Hospital in [[New London, Connecticut]].<ref name=USU2011/>
==Honors and awards== Honors and awards that Zimble has received include:<ref name=USU2011/> {| |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=Defense Distinguished Service ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Defense Distinguished Service Medal]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=Navy Distinguished Service ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Navy Distinguished Service Medal]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=2|type=award-star|ribbon=Legion of Merit ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Legion of Merit]] (three awards) |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=Defense Meritorious Service ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Defense Meritorious Service Medal]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=Meritorious Service ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Service Medal]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=US Defense Superior Service Medal ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Defense Superior Service Medal]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=Navy and Marine Corps Commendation ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Navy Commendation Medal]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=SGMedRib.gif|width=60}} |[[Surgeon General's Medallion]] ([[United States Public Health Service]]) |} {| |Honorary [[Doctor of Science]] degree from the [[State University of New York Upstate Medical University|State University of New York at Syracuse]] |- |Frank Brown Berry Prize in Federal Health Care |- |Founder's Medal ([[Association of Military Surgeons of the United States]]) |- |Distinguished Service Award (Naval Reserve Association) |- |United States Army [[Order of Military Medical Merit]] |}
==References== {{reflist}}
